clinical_study.brief_title: Acquired Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis (EV) Syndrome in HIV-infected Pediatric Patients
clinical_study.official_title: Acquired Epidermodysplasia Verruciformis (EV) Syndrome in HIV-infected Pediatric Patients: Prospective Treatment Trial With Topical Glycolic Acid and HPV Genotype Characterization

brief_summary.textblock: Many human immunodeficiency virus (HIV)-positive children are afflicted with diffuse flat warts that have been recalcitrant to multiple treatments.The aim of this prospective study was to evaluate the efficacy, safety and tolerability of 15% glycolic acid lotion (NeoStrata) for treatment of flat warts in HIV-positive children in Botswana. Additionally, the investigators characterized the flat warts in this population, including Human Papillomavirus (HPV) type(s) and degree of immunosuppression within the patients.

primary_outcome.measure: Treatment efficacy of 15% glycolic acid lotion for flat warts
primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were evaluated every two weeks for eight weeks and monthly for the next eight weeks, for a total monitoring period of 16 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Our primary objective is to determine the efficacy of 15% glycolic acid lotion for improving the cosmetic appearance of flat warts in HIV infected children and young adults on antiretroviral therapy.

primary_outcome.measure: Safety and tolerability of 15% glycolic acid lotion for flat warts
primary_outcome.time_frame: Patients were evaluated every two weeks for eight weeks and monthly for the next eight weeks, for a total monitoring period of 16 weeks.
primary_outcome.description: Patients were evaluated for possible side effects of the topical medication, including erythema, scaling, burning, and irritation of the skin in the area applied.

secondary_outcome.measure: HPV typing in EV-like flat warts
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Biopsies were taken at the first visit, and the HPV typing was performed on all samples after the 16 week monitoring period was complete.
secondary_outcome.description: Characterize the HPV types in the flat warts in this population.

arm_group.description: All who met the study criteria commenced once daily use of 15% glycolic acid lotion.

intervention.description: Those who met the study criteria commenced once daily use of 15% glycolic acid lotion to the face and/or dorsal hands, with an increase to twice daily application as tolerated after two weeks of use.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male or female HIV-positive patients 7 years of age or older with at least 15 flat warts, diagnosed clinically by one dermatologist (RLM), on the face and/or dorsal hands were included in the study.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Key exclusion criteria included current use of potential wart treatments or other topical OTC products on the affected area(s).

clinical_study.keyword: The efficacy, tolerability and safety of 15% glycolic acid lotion for treatment of diffuse flat warts among HIV+ children were investigated
